title: Ireland labels Boris Johnson’s reported backstop plan a ‘non-starter’
text:
Boris Johnson (L) meets Simon Coveney | Jack Taylor - WPA Pool via Getty Images Ireland labels Boris Johnson’s reported backstop plan a ‘non-starter’ UK PM wants to replace Irish backstop with customs checkpoints on either side of the border.

Irish Deputy Prime Minister Simon Coveney said Boris Johnson’s reported plan to construct customs checkpoints a few kilometers either side of the Irish border was a "non-starter" and not a serious proposal.

Irish broadcaster RTE reported late Monday that the British PM’s new plan for the Irish border involved an "all-Ireland" trade zone limited largely to food and agriculture, with other imports and exports required to pass through newly constructed customs clearing centers between five and 10 miles back from the Irish border on either side. According to RTE, the information came from technical papers, officially called “non-papers,” sent by London to Brussels.

Responding on Twitter, Coveney said: "Non-Paper = Non-Starter. Time the EU had a serious proposal from the UK Govt if a #Brexit deal is to be achievable in October. NI and IRE deserves better!"

Following up on the story, the U.K.'s Daily Telegraph newspaper reported Johnson would present his new proposals, including those related to the clearing centers, to EU officials this week.
description: UK PM wants to replace Irish backstop with customs checkpoints on either side of the border.
